title: No Corrections: June 15, 2020
description: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, June 15, 2020.
content: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, June 15, 2020.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Amid Revolt, Bosses Sun in Hamptons
description: Quotation of the Day for Monday, June 15, 2020.
content: “Being a leader means staying with your people and seeing what they see.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Austin Frakt
title: How to Think About Pregnancy Risks
description: Individual choices matter, but public policies are more important.
content: Advice about pregnancy has become so prevalent that it has become almost an industry unto itself. Personal behavior can be important, but relative to a lot of the expectations heaped on pregnant women, it can also easily be overstated.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Giovanni Russonello
title: A Killing in Atlanta Stirs Fresh Anger
description: New arguments on defunding vs. restructuring the police: This is your morning tip sheet.
content: Streets say “defund,” Dems hear “restructure.” It’s Monday, and this is your politics tip sheet.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Captain of the Day Traders
description: Wall Street increasingly thinks the recent market rally is driven by retail investors, particularly bored sports gamblers looking for action.
content: Want this in your inbox each morning? Sign up here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Blinder and Talya Minsberg
title: Inside the Sophisticated Campaign to Save Men’s Running at Brown
description: Men’s cross-country and track and field were demoted at one of America’s most prestigious universities, until they weren’t. But this is no blueprint for other canceled teams.
content: Fergal Mullen, a venture capitalist in Europe, spent the end of May resigned to a sobering prospect: The varsity men’s cross-country and track and field teams at Brown, where he had been a team captain in 1988, would be shut down.
source.name: The New York Times

title: What You Get for $3.2 Million in California
description: A Carpenter Gothic home in Napa, a midcentury-modern house in Palm Springs and a cottage in Carmel-by-the-Sea.
content: A Carpenter Gothic home in Napa, a midcentury-modern house in Palm Springs and a cottage in Carmel-by-the-Sea.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Anything But Candy Land!
description: Board games fill me with existential dread.
content: I have a confession: I hate board games.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: What to Cook Right Now
description: Make the chef Dolester Miles’s coconut pecan cake, and end up with a cake to astonish yourself and your loved ones.
content: Good morning. You know that sense of satisfaction you get, cooking good food? Not just in making a recipe you found and having it come out edible, but in making it well, making it delicious, making it nice? Imagine how you’ll feel when you’re done with this coconut pecan cake (above) that the pastry chef Dolester Miles makes at Chez Fonfon and Bottega, and occasionally at Highlands Bar and Grill, Frank and Pardis Stitt’s restaurants in Birmingham, Ala.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roni Caryn Rabin
title: The Pandemic Claims New Victims: Prestigious Medical Journals
description: Two major study retractions in one month have left researchers wondering if the peer review process is broken.
content: One study promised that popular blood-pressure drugs were safe for people infected with the coronavirus. Another paper warned that anti-malaria drugs endorsed by President Trump actually were dangerous to these patients.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ezekiel J. Emanuel and Rahm Emanuel
title: A Deal to Save Medicaid, the Unemployed and State Budgets
description: The tradeoff: full federal funding for expanded Medicaid and unemployment aid, while states fund early childhood programs and infrastructure.
content: Covid-19’s economic devastation has revealed gaping holes in our safety net, as decades-old structures for Medicaid and unemployment insurance are compounding the pain caused by disease and job loss. Let’s be honest, we would not today design them as they were created. The CARES Act took steps to fix these programs, but they need permanent institutional reform and modernization.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angela Serratore
title: $3.2 Million Homes in California
description: A Carpenter Gothic home in Napa, a midcentury-modern house in Palm Springs and a cottage in Carmel-by-the-Sea.
content: Built as the home of Johnson Horrell, a Napa County judge, and his wife, Sarah, this house was the first on its block. In 1890, it was moved to a new lot, now within walking distance of downtown Napa. In the late 1940s, the house was subdivided into apartments. The current owner, who bought it in 2015, turned it back into a single-family house and did an extensive renovation to restore its original splendor, using raw materials sourced from the house.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak and Alicia Parlapiano
title: The Major Supreme Court Cases This Term and What the Public Thinks
description: The public generally supports the politically liberal position in the cases, though Democrats and Republicans are deeply divided over several of them.
content: The public generally supports the politically liberal position in the cases, though Democrats and Republicans are deeply divided over several of them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melina Delkic
title: Your Tuesday Briefing
description: China outbreak, markets, Russia’s migrant workers: Here’s what you need to know.
content: Some residential compounds in Beijing were under lockdown on Monday and tens of thousands were tested for the coronavirus as the government rushed to contain a new cluster of infections.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Damien Cave, Motoko Rich and Jack Ewing
title: Break the China Habit? Lobsters, Lights and Toilets Show How Hard It Is
description: The risks of relying economically on the Asian superpower have never seemed clearer. But as the world tries to get moving again, it needs China more than ever.
content: As the coronavirus pandemic amplifies longstanding concerns over the world’s economic dependence on China, many countries are trying to reduce their exposure to Beijing’s brand of business.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shaila Dewan
title: Police Chiefs Are Finding Job Security Is Hard to Come By
description: Chiefs who promise reform must find a way to satisfy local officials, the police and their union, and a public that is increasingly critical of police tactics and behavior.
content: Erika Shields was not your old-line, law-and-order police chief.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Erlanger
title: With Brexit Trade Talks at an Impasse, Boris Johnson Finally Engages
description: The British prime minister held talks with European Union leaders and agreed to accelerate negotiations on a future trading relationship to try to avoid a brutal break at the end of December.
content: BRUSSELS — Prime Minister Boris Johnson of Britain, in his first direct talks with Brussels about Brexit since his country left the European Union at the end of January, agreed with European leaders on Monday to push ahead with intensified talks in July and August to try to reach a trade deal by the end of the year.
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘Say Thank You Say I’m Sorry’
description: The Pulitzer Prize-winning poet Jericho Brown writes for the Book Review about life during the pandemic.
content: This week, the Book Review asked two prominent American poets to write original poems responding to this historic moment in our country. Claudia Rankine, whose poem “Weather” appears on the front cover of the June 21 issue, is the author of “Citizen: An American Lyric” and other collections, as well as two plays and various essays. She teaches at Yale. Her new book, “Just Us: An American Conversation,” will be published in September. Jericho Brown’s third volume of poetry, “The Tradition,” won the 2020 Pulitzer Prize for poetry. His poem “Say Thank You Say I’m Sorry” appears here and on the back page of the issue.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sandomir
title: Alan Hurwitz, Teacher Who Turned to Bank Heists, Dies at 79
description: Once a respected educator in Detroit, he developed a crack addiction and robbed 18 banks in three months, earning the name the “Zombie Bandit.” He died of Covid-19.
content: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By George Gene Gustines
title: At 99, Al Jaffee Says Goodbye to Mad Magazine
description: As a send-off for the cartoonist, the satirical publication has prepared an all-Jaffee issue that includes his final Fold-In.
content: Mad magazine is celebrating its longest-tenured contributor, Al Jaffee, with an issue devoted to him on the occasion of his retirement.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angela Serratore
title: $3.2 Million Homes in California
description: A Carpenter Gothic home in Napa, a midcentury-modern house in Palm Springs and a cottage in Carmel-by-the-Sea.
content: Built as the home of Johnson Horrell, a Napa County judge, and his wife, Sarah, this house was the first on its block. In 1890, it was moved to a new lot, now within walking distance of downtown Napa. In the late 1940s, the house was subdivided into apartments. The current owner, who bought it in 2015, turned it back into a single-family house and did an extensive renovation to restore its original splendor, using raw materials sourced from the house.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jerald Brooks and Lakesha Bailey
title: We’re Feeding America, but We’re Sacrificing Ourselves
description: Poultry plants continue to run processing lines at a breakneck speed, making it impossible for workers to social distance.
content: You’re a worker at a Tyson Foods poultry plant and still punching in even though the coronavirus continues to run rampant through meat-processing plants across the country. You’re proud that your job helps keep supermarkets stocked. Your family supports Donald Trump. But the president’s executive order to keep meat plants open — issued after the Tyson Foods chairman, John Tyson, publicly warned of supply shortages — worries you. You think company leadership pushed for plants to stay open and to run at top speed instead of doing more to keep workers safe. This is the reality for Jerald Brooks, a Tyson poultry processing plant worker in Glen Allen, Va. He is not alone.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Penelope Green
title: Ralph Caplan, Design Critic Big on Sit-Ins but Not Chairs, Dies at 95
description: A writer, editor and consultant, his views on American product design allowed him to stray into a wide range of cultural issues, including the battle for civil rights.
content: Ralph Caplan was the E.B. White of design writing. He disliked windy sentences and pompous clichés and was always ready to poke fun at orthodoxies. He said he wasn’t sure he saw the point of a chair, since human beings could sit on pretty much anything except a cactus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Danny Hakim and Stephanie Saul
title: The Rising Trump Lawyer Battling to Reshape the Electorate
description: He’s argued against affirmative action at Harvard and abortion in Georgia. Now he has a leading role as Republicans push a new wave of voting measures across the U.S.
content: As victory laps go, it was remarkably low-key.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jane E. Brody
title: Looking at Masks and Respiratory Health
description: Even without a mask as an impediment, many people breathe in ways that compromise their well-being.
content: Starting with the first reports of breathing difficulties among people who contracted Covid-19 and extending now to those wearing masks to limit the risk of acquiring or unwittingly transmitting the virus, the ability to breathe normally has become a common concern.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: ‘Troubling Tableau’ in 11th Circuit’s Prisoner Cases, Sotomayor Says
description: The appeals court, which covers three Southern states, uses procedures “out of step with other courts,” Justice Sonia Sotomayor wrote, echoing critiques from judges and scholars.
content: WASHINGTON — It is not easy for prisoners to challenge their convictions in federal courts anywhere in the nation. But it is especially tough in the United States Court of Appeals for the 11th Circuit, which hears appeals from Alabama, Florida and Georgia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Giulia McDonnell Nieto del Rio
title: Oluwatoyin Salau, Missing Black Lives Matter Activist, Is Found Dead
description: Ms. Salau, 19, was found dead along with a 75-year-old woman in Tallahassee, Fla., the police said. Their deaths are being investigated as homicides.
content: A 19-year-old Black Lives Matter activist whose disappearance this month led to a desperate search after she sent a series of tweets describing a sexual assault has been found dead in Tallahassee, Fla., the police said Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noam Scheiber
title: Gay Rights Ruling Pushes Workplace Dynamic Already in Motion
description: The Supreme Court decision gives plaintiffs leverage, but companies large and small are still expected to face legal cases over their policies.
content: When a Walmart associate named Jacqueline Cote filed a charge with the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission in 2014 contending that the company was discriminating against her by denying health insurance benefits to her same-sex spouse, it signaled the beginning of a drawn-out legal battle.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth Dias
title: Conservative Christians See ‘Seismic Implications’ in Supreme Court Ruling
description: A ruling that protects the rights of gay and transgender workers could impact how conservative groups operate their own institutions.
content: WASHINGTON — For conservative Christian groups, Monday’s Supreme Court ruling protecting the rights of gay and transgender workers was not only the latest sign that they are losing the American culture wars over sexuality. It also caused widespread concern that it could affect how they operate their own institutions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor and Alexandra Alter
title: Trump’s Niece to Publish Book With ‘Harrowing’ Revelations
description: Mary Trump will say that she was a source of The New York Times’s coverage of the president’s tax returns. The Times declined to comment on the claim.
content: A niece of President Trump will divulge a series of damaging stories about him in an upcoming book, the first time that the president could be forced to grapple with unflattering revelations by a member of his own family.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Giulia McDonnell Nieto del Rio
title: Oluwatoyin Salau, Missing Black Lives Matter Activist, Is Found Dead
description: Ms. Salau, 19, was found dead along with a 75-year-old woman in Tallahassee, Fla., the police said. Their deaths are being investigated as homicides.
content: A 19-year-old Black Lives Matter activist whose disappearance this month led to a desperate search after she sent a series of tweets describing a sexual assault has been found dead in Tallahassee, Fla., the police said Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jane E. Brody
title: Looking at Masks and Respiratory Health
description: Even without a mask as an impediment, many people breathe in ways that compromise their well-being.
content: Starting with the first reports of breathing difficulties among people who contracted Covid-19 and extending now to those wearing masks to limit the risk of acquiring or unwittingly transmitting the virus, the ability to breathe normally has become a common concern.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: ‘Troubling Tableau’ in 11th Circuit’s Prisoner Cases, Sotomayor Says
description: The appeals court, which covers three Southern states, uses procedures “out of step with other courts,” Justice Sonia Sotomayor wrote, echoing critiques from judges and scholars.
content: WASHINGTON — It is not easy for prisoners to challenge their convictions in federal courts anywhere in the nation. But it is especially tough in the United States Court of Appeals for the 11th Circuit, which hears appeals from Alabama, Florida and Georgia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noam Scheiber
title: Gay Rights Ruling Pushes Workplace Dynamic Already in Motion
description: The Supreme Court decision gives plaintiffs leverage, but companies large and small are still expected to face legal cases over their policies.
content: When a Walmart associate named Jacqueline Cote filed a charge with the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission in 2014 contending that the company was discriminating against her by denying health insurance benefits to her same-sex spouse, it signaled the beginning of a drawn-out legal battle.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth Dias
title: Conservative Christians See ‘Seismic Implications’ in Supreme Court Ruling
description: A ruling that protects the rights of gay and transgender workers could impact how conservative groups operate their own institutions.
content: WASHINGTON — For conservative Christian groups, Monday’s Supreme Court ruling protecting the rights of gay and transgender workers was not only the latest sign that they are losing the American culture wars over sexuality. It also caused widespread concern that it could affect how they operate their own institutions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Danny Hakim and Stephanie Saul
title: The Rising Trump Lawyer Battling to Reshape the Electorate
description: He’s argued against affirmative action at Harvard and abortion in Georgia. Now he has a leading role as Republicans push a new wave of voting measures across the U.S.
content: As victory laps go, it was remarkably low-key.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sandra E. Garcia
title: Where Did BIPOC Come From?
description: The acronym, which stands for black, Indigenous and people of color, is suddenly everywhere. Is it doing its job?
content: Black Americans have been called by many names in the United States. African American, Negro, colored and the unutterable slur that rhymes with bigger. In recent weeks, as protests against police brutality and racism have flooded the streets and social media, another more inclusive term has been ascribed to the population: BIPOC.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anne Daugherty
title: How Paradise High’s Class of 2020 Got Its Graduation
description: The students and parents pushed and prodded over 10 weeks for an exception to Gov. Gavin Newsom’s shelter-in-place order.
content: Good morning.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Libbey
title: What’s on TV Monday: ‘Original Cast Album: Company’ and ‘Songland’
description: A behind-the-scenes documentary by D.A. Pennebaker drops on the Criterion Channel. And Usher closes out the second season of a songwriting competition show.
content: ORIGINAL CAST ALBUM: COMPANY (1970) Stream on the Criterion Channel. Stephen Sondheim’s formally adventurous 1970 Broadway musical about modern relationship issues is viewed by many as his breakout work as an independent creative force. D.A. Pennebaker, the filmmaker known for his documentary work on the upheaval and music of the 1960s and ’70s, was on hand when the original cast gathered at “The Church,” a Columbia Records studio in Midtown Manhattan, to record the show’s cast album. Sondheim is featured in the documentary, as is Elaine Stritch, who played Joanne, and other performers. Among the songs captured are “Another Hundred People” and “The Ladies Who Lunch.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim McKeough
title: Shopping for String Lights
description: Because in a summer of social distancing, we could all use a little festivity.
content: Outdoor string lights have surged in popularity, thanks to their ability to make a simple backyard or patio feel like a romantic outdoor cafe. And that makes them especially appealing during a summer of social distancing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Higgins
title: Putin Says U.S. Is in ‘Deep Internal Crisis’
description: The Russian leader described an America poisoned by racism and violence and paralyzed by the refusal of President Trump’s opponents to accept the 2016 election results.
content: MOSCOW — President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia on Sunday described the United States as a country gripped by a “deep internal crisis” and attributed it to what he said was a refusal by opponents of President Trump to accept his “obvious” 2016 election victory and his legitimacy as leader.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Benanav
title: Portraits of Everyday Life in the Indian State of Gujarat
description: In India’s westernmost state, philosophies of asceticism live side-by-side with those of raw capitalism.
content: With travel restrictions in place worldwide, we’ve launched a new series, The World Through a Lens, in which photojournalists help transport you, virtually, to some of our planet’s most beautiful and intriguing places. This week, Michael Benanav shares a collection of portraits from Gujarat, a state in western India.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Long, Complicated History of ‘Urban’ Music
description: As the music industry reckons with racial inequality, one of the first old structures to fall has been a term that dates back to the 1970s.
content: The ongoing protests against police brutality in the United States are beginning to bring wider change and reflection. Over the last two weeks, that’s meant that the music business, long a site of racial inequity, has been the subject of a reckoning. One of the first old structures to fall has been the category “urban” music, a quirk of nomenclature that goes back more than four decades, and has become such an elastic term that it’s almost lost all meaning.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shira Ovide
title: One Restaurant’s Survival Guide
description: This restaurant was forced to get creative with its use of technology — and to forgo the apps.
content: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it weekdays.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Perri Klass, M.D
title: The Impact of Disparities on Children’s Health
description: Differences in access to medical care and treatment contribute to conditions that disproportionately hurt minority children.
content: You might not have noticed it (there’s a lot going on) but there was some good news last week in a study in JAMA that suggested that racial disparities in extremely premature infants were shrinking. The study looked at more than 20,000 extremely preterm infants (22 to 27 weeks gestation) born from 2002 to 2016. Mortality rates dropped over the course of the study, and though serious infections were more frequent in black and Hispanic infants early on, the rates converged with those of white infants as time went on.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jerald Brooks and Lakesha Bailey
title: We’re Feeding America, but We’re Sacrificing Ourselves
description: Tyson Foods continues to run its processing lines at a breakneck speed, making it impossible for workers to social distance
content: Tyson Foods continues to run its processing lines at a breakneck speed, making it impossible for workers to social distance
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Clark
title: Make a Compound Butter, and Use It on Your Next Meal
description: Add herbs and some alliums to a stick of butter for a lot of flavor.
content: The term “compound butter” doesn’t sound very delicious. If you weren’t already familiar with its creamy, herb-speckled joys, you might decide to give it a pass.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jerrelle Guy
title: Sweet, Tender and Studded With Strawberries
description: This cousin to spoonbread and pudding cake is best served warm, with a scoop of vanilla ice cream.
content: There’s something so homey about a warm dessert so tender you must serve it with a big spoon and a deep bowl. Depending on the occasion, there are a couple of recipes you could try.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Ways to Support Black Farmers, Restaurants and Nonprofits
description: The Museum of Food and Drink has added a BLM Community Resources page to its website, along with a preview of its new “African/American” exhibition.
content: BLM Community Resources, on the website for the Museum of Food and Drink, lists scores of black-owned farms, restaurants, food resources in black communities and charities. Among them a flower farm that Walker Marsh developed on what was an empty lot in Baltimore, and a fund-raiser for the family of David McAtee, the barbecue chef who was shot and killed this month in Louisville, Ky. The museum is asking for public opinion as the webpage evolves. The website also has a preview of “African/American: Making the Nation’s Table,” an exhibition that has been postponed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press
title: Atlanta Mayor Announces Police Reforms With a Series of Executive Orders
description: Mayor Keisha Lance Bottoms announced on Monday a series of police reforms for the Atlanta Police Department after the fatal shooting of Rayshard Brooks.
content: Mayor Keisha Lance Bottoms announced on Monday a series of police reforms for the Atlanta Police Department after the fatal shooting of Rayshard Brooks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rick Rojas and Richard Fausset
title: Police Killings Prompt Reassessment of Laws Allowing Deadly Force
description: The continuing deaths of black people by the police are undermining support for the wide latitude officers are given in cases in which an encounter ends in a death.
content: ATLANTA — The swift decision on Sunday to fire the white Atlanta police officer who shot and killed a black motorist intensified the growing re-examination of the use of deadly force by the police, challenging longstanding principles that have given law enforcement officers wide latitude in cases in which an encounter ends with a death.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Lerer
title: Pride Goeth, or Is It Gone?
description: As many Americans lose faith in the future, fewer say they’re very proud to be Americans at all.
content: Hi. Welcome to On Politics, your guide to the day in national politics. I’m Lisa Lerer, your host.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Civil Rights Law Protects Gay and Transgender Workers, Supreme Court Rules
description: The court said the language of the Civil Rights Act of 1964, which prohibits sex discrimination, applies to discrimination based on sexual orientation and gender identity.
content: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court ruled on Monday that a landmark civil rights law protects gay and transgender workers from workplace discrimination, handing the movement for L.G.B.T. equality a long-sought and unexpected victory.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rory Smith
title: The Quiet Bazaar: Soccer’s Transfer Market Braces for the Unknown
description: As clubs try to estimate the full scale of the damage of the coronavirus shutdown, this summer’s deals could herald a transformation in the balance of power.
content: If you are enjoying this newsletter every week, please pass it on to a friend (or four) and tell them to sign up at nytimes.com/rory.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bill Pennington
title: The PGA Tour’s Return Offered a How-to Guide for Other Leagues
description: Golfers went from carping about swab testing to nearly forgetting about social distancing between the ropes, proving a sports truism: Athletes adjust and always keep their eyes on the prize(s).
content: Daniel Berger earned $1.35 million Sunday for winning the PGA Tour’s first tournament after a three-month layoff caused by the coronavirus pandemic. But on Monday Berger was entitled to something more precious: a first-class seat on the special flight the tour chartered to safely shuttle players and their caddies to the next event on the tour.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David McCabe
title: Amazon Says Jeff Bezos Is Willing to Testify Before Congress
description: Lawmakers had requested that he testify as part of their antitrust investigation into the big tech companies.
content: WASHINGTON — Jeff Bezos, Amazon’s chief executive, is willing to testify before a House antitrust investigation into the market power of major tech companies alongside other chief executives, a lawyer for Amazon wrote to lawmakers on Sunday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jed Kolko
title: Don’t Cheer Too Soon. Keep an Eye on the Core Jobless Rate.
description: The drop in the headline unemployment number could be offering false hope.
content: The recent jobs report for May seemed to bring good news: more jobs and lower unemployment. But the coronavirus pandemic has broken most economic charts and models, and all the numbers we regularly watch need a closer look. The decline in unemployment was actually driven by a drop in temporary layoffs. Strip those out, and what remains — let’s call it the core unemployment rate — rose in May.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jan Ransom
title: After Rift Over Protests, N.Y.P.D. Pulls Out of Prosecutors’ Offices
description: The police commissioner said the timing had nothing to do with the prosecutors’ decisions to drop charges against certain protesters, but it seemed to reflect a growing divide.
content: A few hours after the Manhattan district attorney announced he would not prosecute some of the protesters who had been arrested during demonstrations against police brutality, the Police Department sent him a message: All the officers assigned to his office would be pulled off the job to help with crowd control.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Fausset and Rick Rojas
title: Atlanta Mayor Tightens Rules on When Police Can Use Force
description: Mayor Keisha Lance Bottoms issued a series of executive orders after the shooting of Rayshard Brooks, which has stirred protests and pushed the city into a broader reckoning over policing.
content: ATLANTA — In the wake of the death of a black motorist by a white Atlanta police officer, the city’s mayor announced on Monday a series of reforms aimed at dramatically overhauling how the Police Department uses force.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shane Goldmacher
title: Hillary Clinton Backs Eliot Engel, in Her First House Primary Endorsement of 2020
description: Mr. Engel, a longtime New York representative, is trying to fend off a serious challenge from his left by Jamaal Bowman, who has been endorsed by Bernie Sanders and Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez.
content: Hillary Clinton delivered her first Democratic primary endorsement in a 2020 House race on Monday, throwing her support behind Representative Eliot L. Engel of New York, who is trying to fend off a serious challenge from his left after more than three decades in Congress.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Frank Bruni
title: The Court-Martial of Donald J. Trump
description: The intensifying rift between the military and the president demands attention.
content: The first time I saw President Trump referred to as “Cadet Bone Spurs” I laughed, the second time I smiled and the third time I cringed. It’s an apt slur, but it lumps him together with all the other politicians whose military huzzahs contradict their personal histories and whose insult to our men and women in uniform can be reduced to dodging the draft.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ivan Nechepurenko and Andrew Higgins
title: Russian Court Sentences American, Paul Whelan, to 16 Years on Spy Charges
description: The case, which Mr. Whelan and U.S. officials dismiss as politically motivated, is the latest blow to President Trump’s goal of improving relations with Moscow.
content: MOSCOW — A court in Moscow on Monday sentenced an American who claims he was framed by Russian agents to 16 years in a high-security prison for espionage, delivering another blow to President Trump’s already faltering efforts to “get along with Russia.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Gutierrez and Alexandra Stevenson
title: Maria Ressa, Crusading Journalist, Is Convicted in Philippines Libel Case
description: The conviction of Ms. Ressa, a critic of President Rodrigo Duterte and his violent drug war, is the latest blow to press freedoms in the country.
content: MANILA — Maria Ressa has been accused of fraud, tax evasion and receiving money from the Central Intelligence Agency. She has been arrested twice and posted bail eight times.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marlise Simons
title: After 13 Years on the Run, a Sudanese Militia Leader Appears in Court
description: A case in the International Criminal Court against Ali Kushayb is the first to address the mass killings of civilians by Sudan’s armed forces and government-backed militias in Darfur.
content: A Sudanese militia leader appeared before the International Criminal Court on Monday, after 13 years on the run, to face charges of war crimes and crimes against humanity committed during the bloody conflict in the Sudanese region of Darfur from 2003 to 2004.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zia ur-Rehman, Salman Masood and Maria Abi-Habib
title: Pakistan’s Lockdown Ended a Month Ago. Now Hospital Signs Read ‘Full.’
description: Medical workers are falling ill in Pakistan at alarming rates as the country registers at least 100,000 new coronavirus cases since the lockdown was lifted.
content: KARACHI — Pakistanis stricken by the coronavirus are being turned away from hospitals that have simply closed their gates and put up signs reading “full house.” Doctors and nurses are falling ill at alarming rates, and are also coming under physical assault from desperate and angry families.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michelle Cottle
title: Ask Not What President Trump Can Do for You
description: His made-for-TV rallies can be matters of life and death.
content: Once again, President Trump is taking heat for treating the presidency like a branding exercise.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: Market Madness in the Pandemic
description: Why are investors rushing to buy junk?
content: After all these years, Hertz is No. 1 again. Not in market share: The car-rental company is a distant second to Enterprise. But Hertz has become Exhibit #1 of the madness that has been sweeping the stock market in these times of Covid-19 — a madness that may do considerable harm, not because stock prices themselves matter all that much, but because Donald Trump and his minions treat the stock market as a measure of their success.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Supreme Court Won’t Hear Case on California Sanctuary Law
description: The case concerned a state law that limits cooperation with agents seeking to detain immigrants released from state custody.
content: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Monday turned down an appeal from the Trump administration seeking to challenge a California “sanctuary law.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Hale
title: Review: ‘Frontline’ Traces the Footsteps of Covid-19
description: Its new report, “The Virus: What Went Wrong?,” recounts the progress of the disease and asks what America missed.
content: “The Virus: What Went Wrong?,” a 90-minute installment of PBS’s “Frontline” premiering Tuesday, resurfaces the story of the pandemic that felt like an inescapable catastrophe just three weeks ago. Making no mention of protests or police, it’s like a courier with an urgent message who lost his place in line.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Declan Walsh
title: Arrested for Waving Rainbow Flag, a Gay Egyptian Takes Her Life
description: Charged with “inciting debauchery,” Sarah Hegazi was jailed and tortured.
content: CAIRO — When the openly gay frontman of a hugely popular Lebanese pop group strutted onto the stage of a Cairo summer festival in 2017, rainbow flags lifted in the air, and something sparked inside Sarah Hegazi.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margot Sanger-Katz and Erica L. Green
title: Supreme Court Expansion of Transgender Rights Undercuts Trump Restrictions
description: The ruling focused on employment discrimination, but legal scholars say its language could force expanded civil rights protections in education, health care, housing and other areas of daily life.
content: WASHINGTON — The Trump administration’s socially conservative agenda has included a broad-based effort to eliminate transgender rights across the government, in education, housing, the military and, as recently as Friday, health care.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse McKinley and Luis Ferré-Sadurní
title: New Yorkers Flattened the Curve. Now They’re Dropping Their Guard.
description: Gov. Cuomo warned that lax adherence to social-distancing rules meant to contain the coronavirus could lead him to slow New York City’s reopening.
content: The critical indicators surrounding the coronavirus crisis in New York have clearly turned a corner: Deaths have slowed to a trickle, new cases have declined sharply and the numbers of hospitalizations and intubations have eased.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Singer
title: Ex-eBay Workers Sent Critics Live Roaches and a Mask of a Bloody Pig Face, U.S. Says
description: Six former employees of the site sent threatening messages and deliveries to a couple after the e-commerce newsletter they published wrote about a lawsuit involving eBay.
content: BOXBOROUGH, Mass. — Six eBay employees mounted a cyberstalking campaign — including sending boxes of live cockroaches and a Halloween mask of a bloody pig’s face — against a couple who ran an online e-commerce newsletter, according to charges filed by federal prosecutors on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eva Holland
title: In a Crisis, We Can Learn From Trauma Therapy
description: Emotional resilience can be deliberately cultivated. But it takes work.
content: This article is the first in a series on resilience in troubled times — what we can learn about it from history and personal experiences.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: How Trump Is Fueling Progressivism
description: And what else you need to know today.
content: If you’re trying to understand why the Black Lives Matter movement has ascended to another level, it’s helpful to think about an idea developed by the political scientist Christopher Wlezien: the thermostat theory of politics.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ivan Nechepurenko and Sergey Ponomarev
title: For Migrants in Russia, Virus Means No Money to Live and No Way to Leave
description: The coronavirus has highlighted migrants’ inferior status in Russia. With no jobs, and sometimes no health care, many want to go home — but find they can’t.
content: MOSCOW — Migrant workers from Central Asia, shrugging off the risk of coronavirus infection, have gathered in groups each day outside their countries’ embassies in Moscow, banging on doors and fences and shouting for officials to come out and tell them when they can finally get on a charter flight home.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Azi Paybarah
title: How New York Is Restricting Police Tactics
description: Governor Andrew Cuomo has signed three measures that overhaul police practices in the aftermath of protests that followed the killing of George Floyd.
content: [Want to get New York Today by email? Here’s the sign-up.]
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Lyons
title: Watch This: ‘America to Me’
description: The layered, nuanced 10-part documentary, which examines race and coming-of-age at a Chicago-area high school is now streaming free.
content: Every Monday, Wednesday and Friday, our TV critic Margaret Lyons offers hyper-specific viewing recommendations in our Watching newsletter. Read her latest picks below, and sign up for the Watching newsletter here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victoria Shannon and Hiroko Masuike
title: Gay Rights, Hydroxychloroquine, Atlanta: Your Monday Evening Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
content: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: Matthew Williams, Collaborator of Kanye West and Lady Gaga, Is Givenchy’s New Designer
description: This is not the house Audrey Hepburn’s image built.
content: Change is coming for Givenchy. The French brand is going to emerge from coronavirus confinement with not just new social distancing rules, but a whole new look. Two months after Clare Waight Keller stepped down as creative director, the house announced that it had named a new designer, and he comes not from the school of couture, but rather the school of Kanye.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ivan Nechepurenko and Sergey Ponomarev
title: For Migrants in Russia, Virus Means No Money to Live and No Way to Leave
description: The coronavirus has highlighted migrants’ inferior status in Russia. With no jobs, and sometimes no health care, many want to go home — but find they can’t.
content: MOSCOW — Migrant workers from Central Asia, shrugging off the risk of coronavirus infection, have gathered in groups each day outside their countries’ embassies in Moscow, banging on doors and fences and shouting for officials to come out and tell them when they can finally get on a charter flight home.
source.name: The New York Times

description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.

title: Watch This: ‘America to Me’
description: The layered, nuanced 10-part documentary, which examines race and coming-of-age at a Chicago-area high school is now streaming free.
content: Every Monday, Wednesday and Friday, our TV critic Margaret Lyons offers hyper-specific viewing recommendations in our Watching newsletter. Read her latest picks below, and sign up for the Watching newsletter here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: Matthew Williams, Collaborator of Kanye West and Lady Gaga, Is Givenchy’s New Designer
description: This is not the house Audrey Hepburn’s image built.
content: Change is coming for Givenchy. The French brand is going to emerge from coronavirus confinement with not just new social distancing rules, but a whole new look. Two months after Clare Waight Keller stepped down as creative director, the house announced that it had named a new designer, and he comes not from the school of couture, but rather the school of Kanye.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Leland
title: Baruch Haviv, Pilot, Landlord and Opera Fan, Dies at 82
description: Mr. Haviv, who came to the United States penniless, believed Hell’s Kitchen had a bright future. He died of the coronavirus.
content: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: This Photography Book Celebrates Black Chefs
description: “Toques in Black,” by the food photographer Battman, features the dishes and stories of more than a hundred African-American chefs.
content: Alan Batt, the food photographer known as Battman, traveled around the country interviewing and photographing black chefs for his latest volume, “Toques in Black.” The book profiles 101 chefs, including the legendary Leah Chase of New Orleans, who died last year. Among the others are Adrienne Cheatham of SundayBest pop-up dinners in Harlem, with uni spoonbread and buttermilk dashi; Digby Stridiron from Braata on St. Croix in the U.S. Virgin Islands offering shrimp escabeche; and JJ Johnson of FieldTrip in New York with whole fried peanut-crusted snapper. Marcus Samuelsson wrote the foreword.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lara Takenaga and Jonathan Wolfe
title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
description: A troubling pattern emerges in parts of the U.S. that began lifting restrictions earlier than others.
content: States in the South, West and Southwest are seeing upticks in their coronavirus case counts — and in some cases setting records — as a troubling pattern emerges in areas that began lifting restrictions earlier than others.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Picnic With Jon Bon Jovi
description: The rocker’s wine is featured in a new picnic to-go from the rooftop bar Versa in Midtown.
content: Picnicking is an easy socially distant gathering for lunch or dinner. Versa, a rooftop bar and restaurant atop the Renaissance New York Midtown hotel, has assembled picnic baskets that can be ordered for delivery on Saturdays or Sundays to eight Manhattan parks, including Bryant Park, the Sheep Meadow and the Mall in Central Park and Hudson River Park. The basic $35 menu consists of a lobster roll from the Lobster Place in Chelsea Market, a bottle of Evian, a face mask and a bottle of Hampton Water, a pale, floral French rosé developed by Jesse Bongiovi and his father, Jon Bon Jovi, in partnership with the winemaker Gérard Bertrand. For $85, you also get an antipasto platter of charcuterie, cheeses, fruit, flatbread and smoked salmon, and some hand sanitizer. At $135, there are two lobster rolls and two bottles of wine and water, a tote bag and a picnic blanket, along with the other items. Versa and Hampton Water are donating to Black Lives Matter and other charities. Delivery is included. Orders must be placed by 5 p.m. Fridays.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Own a Piece of the Ritz
description: An online auction offers martini glasses from Bar Hemingway, along with a history of the Parisian hotel.
content: Would you like to own a set of six crystal Bar Hemingway martini glasses from the Ritz in Paris? At an auction from Sunday through Tuesday of tableware and other artifacts from the hotel, there are four lots of these, estimated at 400 to 600 euros (around $450 to $680). Or if your dining area lacks a silver-trimmed tableside gueridon from which to serve the pepperoni pie just delivered from the local pizzeria, there are those, too. The auction is live and online; the digital catalog of nearly 1,500 lots provides the window-shopping, along with a history of the hotel.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman and Jessica Testa
title: When Pyer Moss Brought Police Brutality to the Runway
description: An oral history of the 2015 show, which resulted in death threats to Kerby Jean-Raymond, but solidified him as a powerful new voice in fashion.
content: In the last two years, Kerby Jean-Raymond, the founder of Pyer Moss, has become something of a New York Fashion Week star, famous for taking the African-American experience and putting it front and center on the runway, using such inspiration figures as the black cowboy and Sister Rosetta Tharpe. He has won the CFDA/Vogue Fashion Fund award, become artistic director of Reebok Studies__ and collaborated with Hennessy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brooks Barnes
title: The 2021 Oscars Will Be Delayed
description: Hollywood’s highest-profile award event will be in April rather than February, and the eligibility period for the film awards will be extended.
content: LOS ANGELES — The Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences said on Monday that it would push back the next Oscars ceremony to April 25 from Feb. 28, citing the coronavirus pandemic. The postponement, the fourth since the Academy Awards were introduced in 1929, could prompt the Golden Globes and other entertainment award shows to recalibrate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Mueller
title: U.S. Pilot Dies in Fighter Jet Crash off British Coast
description: A search and rescue team found the Air Force pilot’s body and wreckage from the F-15C plane in the North Sea. The pilot’s name has not yet been released.
content: LONDON — A United States Air Force pilot was killed on Monday when a fighter jet crashed during a routine training flight off the northeast coast of England, the Air Force said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bill Pennington
title: A Nerve-Racking Final Round Adds Drama to Golf’s Fan-Free Return
description: Daniel Berger forced a playoff with Collin Morikawa by sinking a birdie putt on the 18th hole, then went on to victory at Colonial Country Club.
content: The PGA Tour returned from a three-month layoff due to the coronavirus pandemic on Thursday. But to golf fans worldwide, the true measure, and appeal, of a tour event is a taut, nerve-racking final round.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ivan Nechepurenko and Sergey Ponomarev
title: For Migrants in Russia, Virus Means No Money to Live and No Way to Leave
description: The coronavirus has highlighted migrants’ inferior status in Russia. With no jobs, and sometimes no health care, many want to go home — but find they can’t.
content: MOSCOW — Migrant workers from Central Asia, shrugging off the risk of coronavirus infection, have gathered in groups each day outside their countries’ embassies in Moscow, banging on doors and fences and shouting for officials to come out and tell them when they can finally get on a charter flight home.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Watch This: ‘America to Me’
description: The layered, nuanced 10-part documentary, which examines race and coming-of-age at a Chicago-area high school is now streaming free.

title: Gay Rights, Hydroxychloroquine, Atlanta: Your Monday Evening Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
content: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

content: Would you like to own a set of six crystal Bar Hemingway martini glasses from the Ritz in Paris? At an auction from Sunday through Tuesday of tableware and other artifacts from the hotel, there are four lots of these, estimated at 400 to 600 euros (around $450 to $680). Or if your dining area lacks a silver-trimmed tableside gueridon from which to serve the pepperoni pie just delivered from the local pizzeria, there are those, too. The auction is live and online; the digital catalog of nearly 1,500 lots provides the window-shopping, along with a history of the hotel.

title: When Pyer Moss Brought Police Brutality to the Runway
description: An oral history of the 2015 show, which resulted in death threats to Kerby Jean-Raymond, but solidified him as a powerful new voice in fashion.
content: In the last two years, Kerby Jean-Raymond, the founder of Pyer Moss, has become something of a New York Fashion Week star, famous for taking the African-American experience and putting it front and center on the runway, using such inspiration figures as the black cowboy and Sister Rosetta Tharpe. He has won the CFDA/Vogue Fashion Fund award, become artistic director of Reebok Studies__ and collaborated with Hennessy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carol Pogash
title: Asian Art Museum to Remove Bust of Patron. That’s Just a Start.
description: The museum will also hold public programs to examine Avery Brundage’s legacy, as well as questions around restitution, and work on “decolonizing’’ the museum.
content: SAN FRANCISCO — For 48 years, visitors to this city’s Asian Art Museum have had to pass the bust of Avery Brundage, its towering patron, an industrialist and former president of the International Olympic Committee. The museum, a jeweled attraction at Civic Center Plaza, was established in 1966 to house his nearly 8,000 art pieces.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amy Zipkin
title: Air Service Was Deeply Cut, but Not to Places Like Lake Placid
description: About 170 small airports around the country get federal subsidies, and far fewer of their flights were disrupted in the pandemic.
content: As commercial air travel plummeted in recent months amid pandemic lockdowns and closings, the few people who did venture forth faced delays, cancellations and confusing social distancing messages.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Buckley
title: Coronavirus Breaches Chinese Capital, Rattling Officials
description: Disease experts said limited bursts of infections were likely to become part of the “new normal” for China.
content: The authorities in Beijing placed a swath of the city under lockdown on Monday and tested tens of thousands of people as they rushed to contain a new coronavirus outbreak that marked an unnerving breach in China’s capital.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Mueller
title: U.S. Pilot Dies in Fighter Jet Crash off British Coast
description: A search and rescue team found the Air Force pilot’s body and wreckage from the F-15C plane in the North Sea. The pilot’s name has not yet been released.
content: LONDON — A United States Air Force pilot was killed on Monday when a fighter jet crashed during a routine training flight off the northeast coast of England, the Air Force said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brooks Barnes
title: The 2021 Oscars Will Be Delayed
description: Hollywood’s highest-profile award event will be in April rather than February, and the eligibility period for the film awards will be extended.
content: LOS ANGELES — The Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences said on Monday that it would push back the next Oscars ceremony to April 25 from Feb. 28, citing the coronavirus pandemic. The postponement, the fourth since the Academy Awards were introduced in 1929, could prompt the Golden Globes and other entertainment award shows to recalibrate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Edward Wong
title: V.O.A. Directors Resign After Bannon Ally Takes Charge of U.S. Media Agency
description: Amanda Bennett and Sandra Sugawara told Voice of America employees that they had offered their resignations to Michael Pack, a conservative activist pushed by President Trump.
content: WASHINGTON — Two veteran journalists in charge of Voice of America, Amanda Bennett and Sandra Sugawara, resigned on Monday as a result of the recent congressional confirmation of a conservative activist and filmmaker to be the head of the agency that oversees the government broadcast organization.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amy Zipkin
title: Air Service Was Deeply Cut, but Not to Places Like Lake Placid
description: About 170 small airports around the country get federal subsidies, and far fewer of their flights were disrupted in the pandemic.
content: As commercial air travel plummeted in recent months amid pandemic lockdowns and closings, the few people who did venture forth faced delays, cancellations and confusing social distancing messages.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jon Pareles
title: Rupert Hine, Synth-Pop Music Producer, Dies at 72
description: He was behind Tina Turner’s “Better Be Good to Me” and hits by the Fixx and Howard Jones. He also made a dozen albums of his own songs.
content: Rupert Hine, a prolific English producer and songwriter who thrived in the synth-pop heyday of the 1980s making hits with Tina Turner, the Fixx and Howard Jones, died on June 4 at his home in Wiltshire, England. He was 72.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Clarey
title: U.S.T.A. Plans to Move Forward With U.S. Open Amid Pandemic
description: The plan for a doubleheader of tournaments at the U.S.T.A. Billie Jean King National Tennis Center still needs formal government approval. And it’s unclear how many players will take part.
content: Despite major challenges created by the coronavirus pandemic, the United States Tennis Association is set to announce this week that it will hold the 2020 United States Open with the support of the men’s and women’s tours.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Fatal Shooting at a Wendy’s in Atlanta
description: A reader says the police should not be called for minor infractions.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tariq Panja
title: Adviser to Manchester City Owner Has Role in Newcastle Sale
description: Ali Jassim, a close business associate of the billionaire who owns Manchester City, is serving as a broker in Saudi Arabia’s efforts to buy the Premier League team Newcastle United.
content: LONDON — A trusted adviser to the billionaire Gulf owner of the English Premier League champion Manchester City has emerged as a key player in discussions to sell another Premier League club, Newcastle United, to a group led by Saudi Arabia’s sovereign wealth fund.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Trump and Transgender Rights
description: The feminists Gloria Steinem and S. Mona Sinha say the administration’s new rule erases trans people’s civil right to health care.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘Weather’
description: The poet Claudia Rankine writes for the Book Review about the climate in America at this moment.
content: This week, the Book Review asked two prominent American poets to write original poems responding to this historic moment in our country. Claudia Rankine, whose poem “Weather” appears here and on the front cover of the June 21 issue, is the author of “Citizen: An American Lyric” and other collections, as well as two plays and various essays. She teaches at Yale. Her new book, “Just Us: An American Conversation,” will be published in September. Jericho Brown’s third volume of poetry, “The Tradition,” won the 2020 Pulitzer Prize for poetry. His poem “Say Thank You Say I’m Sorry” appears on the back page of the issue.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear
title: Gorsuch, Conservative Favorite Appointed by Trump, Leads Way on Landmark Decision
description: One conservative group said the justice’s opinion in the L.G.B.T. rights case had betrayed the legacy of Justice Antonin Scalia, whose seat on the court he has held since 2017.
content: WASHINGTON — Justice Neil M. Gorsuch is a profoundly conservative jurist and one of the two appointments President Trump has made to the Supreme Court that Republicans expected would fundamentally shape it to their liking for a generation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Nagourney and Jeremy W. Peters
title: A Half-Century On, an Unexpected Milestone for L.G.B.T.Q. Rights
description: The Supreme Court’s surprising 6-to-3 ruling in favor of gay and transgender rights was perhaps the strongest evidence yet of how fundamentally and unpredictably American views have changed.
content: When Donald J. Trump was elected president, gay and lesbian leaders warned that their far-reaching victories under Barack Obama — including the Supreme Court’s decision legalizing same-sex marriage in 2015 — were in peril, endangered by the imminent arrival of scores of conservative judges and full Republican control of the federal government.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Johnny Diaz
title: Kansas City Police Investigate Vandalism of Memorial to Lynching Victim
description: The memorial to Levi Harrington, a black man killed in Kansas City, Mo., in the 1880s, had been vandalized before.
content: The authorities are investigating the vandalism of a sign that memorialized a Missouri man, Levi Harrington, who was lynched in the 1880s, the police in Kansas City, Mo., said on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth Paton
title: What We Learned From London Fashion Week
description: The first fully digital fashion week from one of the four fashion capitals just ended. Was it any good?
content: LONDON — This past weekend was always going to be unlike any London Fashion Week before.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marcus J. Moore
title: ‘Was It a Lost Psych-Funk Classic?’ It’s Khruangbin, Right Now
description: The Houston trio’s third album adds a new chapter to the band’s improbable story.
content: In 2013, the producer and D.J. Bonobo released his version of “Late Night Tales,” the long-running musician-curated album series. The compilation’s theme was serene songs meant to soundtrack the night, and he included “A Calf Born in Winter” from a band called Khruangbin, an upstart Houston trio that hadn’t yet made a full album.
source.name: The New York Times

title: What We’ve Learned About the Coronavirus
description: Six months into the pandemic, we take stock of where we are, and where we might be going.
content: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device:Via Apple Podcasts | Via Spotify | Via Stitcher
source.name: The New York Times

author: By William J. Broad
title: China Reports Progress in Ultra-Secure Satellite Transmission
description: Researchers enlisted quantum physics to send a “secret key” for encrypting and decrypting messages between two stations 700 miles apart.
content: The world of artificial satellites, silent in the void of space, might seem pacific. In fact it’s a high-flying battlefield rife with jamming, snooping, blinding, spoofing, hacking and hostility among the planet’s growing array of spacecraft and space powers. Now, Chinese scientists report new progress in building what appears to be the first unbreakable information link between an orbiting craft and its terrestrial controllers, raising the odds that Beijing may one day possess a super-secure global communications network.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Stocks Climb After Fed Details Bond-Buying Plan: Live Updates
description: The latest on stock market and business news during the coronavirus outbreak.
content: The Federal Reserve said on Monday that it would begin to buy debt issued by individual corporations based on a broad index of corporate bonds in the United States, a new step in the central bank’s efforts to keep credit flowing freely amid the coronavirus pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Caron and Cheriss May
title: Portraits of Families in Protest
description: Parents actively show their children how to speak out and take a stand against inequality.
content: J. Jioni Palmer, a father of two young boys, couldn’t sleep.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reuters
title: U.N. Removes Saudi-Led Coalition From Child-Killer Blacklist
description: The coalition was first added to the list several years ago for killing and injuring children in Yemen — including 222 last year, despite its being delisted Monday.
content: NEW YORK — U.N. Secretary-General Antonio Guterres on Monday removed a Saudi Arabia-led military coalition from an annual U.N. blacklist, several years after it was first named and shamed for killing and injuring children in Yemen.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Friedman
title: A War Against Climate Science, Waged by Washington’s Rank and File
description: Efforts to block research on climate change don’t just come from the Trump political appointees on top. Lower managers in government are taking their cues, and running with them.
content: WASHINGTON — Efforts to undermine climate change science in the federal government, once orchestrated largely by President Trump’s political appointees, are now increasingly driven by midlevel managers trying to protect their jobs and budgets and wary of the scrutiny of senior officials, according to interviews and newly revealed reports and surveys.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: A Hot Honey to Elevate Your Meal
description: Drizzle this honey, from a South Carolina hot sauce maker, over chicken or pizza for a bit of heat.
content: Red Clay, a company in Charleston, S.C., specializes in hot sauces, and just a trace of their new honey will elevate chicken — preferably fried, though grilled or roasted will do — with a touch of mellowness that has subtle bite. There’s more upfront heat, along with a vegetal note, in the company’s Barrel Aged Hot-Hot Honey. Geoff Rhyne, a chef who is also the company’s hot sauce alchemist, uses the leftover habanero pepper mash from making his hot sauces (like the Carolina-style bolstered with vinegar, and a rich verde variety) to season the honeys.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: A Platform for Your Wine Bottle
description: This brass trivet from the Glass House in Connecticut is a good fit for the dinner table.
content: An unusual brass wine coaster just landed in the gift shop at the Glass House, the Philip Johnson residence in New Canaan, Conn., that’s now a museum. It has a bulge in the middle to fit the punt, or depression, at the bottom of most wine bottles, making it look, ever so slightly, like the sculpture of a fried egg. Eventual scratches are said to be part of its charm. It was created by Claesson Koivisto Rune, a Swedish design group, for Skultuna 1607.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Haag
title: 25 Million Applications: The Scramble for N.Y.C. Affordable Housing
description: Entrants to the city’s housing lottery have waited years, through a tiresome and complex process. Now the system is getting an overhaul.
content: For more than five years, William Sencion did the same task over and over. He signed onto the New York City’s housing lottery site and applied for one of the city’s highly coveted, below-market apartments. Each time, he got the same response: silence.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nancy Wartik
title: How to Donate Blood
description: What you need to know about donating in a time of crisis.
content: As the coronavirus spread across the country, the nation’s blood supply faced a dire shortage. Blood drives were canceled when businesses closed, and many people feared going into donation centers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Marchese
title: Jon Stewart Is Back to Weigh In
description: In the five years since Jon Stewart left ‘The Daily Show,’ American politics has been in a state of constant turmoil and he has remained mostly out of the spotlight.
content: In the five years since Jon Stewart left ‘The Daily Show,’ American politics has been in a state of constant turmoil and he has remained mostly out of the spotlight.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press
title: California Attorney General Pushes Series of Recommended Measures for Police
description: The attorney general of California, Xavier Becerra, also said he was sending investigators to Palmdale, Calif., to look into the death of Robert Fuller, a young black man found hanged from a tree near City Hall.
content: The attorney general of California, Xavier Becerra, also said he was sending investigators to Palmdale, Calif., to look into the death of Robert Fuller, a young black man found hanged from a tree near City Hall.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ali Watkins
title: N.Y.P.D. Disbands Plainclothes Units Involved in Many Shootings
description: The commissioner is reassigning about 600 officers from teams that target violent crime. He called it a “seismic shift” in police culture.
content: The New York police commissioner announced on Monday that he was disbanding the Police Department’s anti-crime units: plainclothes teams that target violent crime and have been involved in some of the city’s most notorious police shootings.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erica L. Green
title: Charter Schools, Some With Billionaire Benefactors, Tap Coronavirus Relief
description: Charter schools, which are publicly funded but privately run, are securing coronavirus relief meant for businesses even as they also benefit from public school aid.
content: WASHINGTON — Charter schools, including some with healthy cash balances and billionaire backers like Michael Bloomberg and Bill Gates, have quietly accepted millions of dollars in emergency coronavirus relief from a fund created to help struggling small businesses stay afloat.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shane Goldmacher
title: Biden and D.N.C. Raised Nearly $81 Million in May, a New High
description: The former vice president had struggled with fund-raising throughout much of the primary campaign, but the pace of giving has sharply increased.
content: Joseph R. Biden Jr. and the Democratic National Committee had, by far, their biggest fund-raising month of the campaign in May, pulling in $80.8 million as large and small donors alike consolidated behind the presumptive Democratic nominee ahead of his fall contest with President Trump.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ali Watkins
title: N.Y.P.D. Disbands Plainclothes Units Involved in Many Shootings
description: The commissioner is reassigning about 600 officers from teams that target violent crime. He called it a “seismic shift” in police culture.
content: The New York police commissioner announced on Monday that he was disbanding the Police Department’s anti-crime units: plainclothes teams that target violent crime and have been involved in some of the city’s most notorious police shootings.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zachary Small
title: Museums Embrace Art Therapy Techniques for Unsettled Times
description: Several institutions are preparing to reopen with an awareness of a new mission as people struggle with loss and unrest.
content: When the instructor asked him to describe his life in two words, Walter Enriquez chose carefully: fear and violence. He had spent decades as a policeman in Peru during the bloodiest days of armed conflict between government forces and guerrilla fighters that killed nearly 70,000 people. But he said that nothing could have prepared him for the extreme isolation and loneliness that come with quarantine. Having lost a handful of his friends and neighbors to the coronavirus pandemic, the 75-year-old retiree has turned toward art therapy programs offered by the Queens Museum to improve his mental health.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Editorial Board
title: Gay Rights Are Civil Rights
description: The Supreme Court says you can’t be fired for being gay or transgender.
content: In an emphatic win for civil rights, equal justice and common sense, the Supreme Court ruled on Monday that federal law bars employers from firing workers for being lesbian, gay, bisexual or transgender.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Bahr
title: After A.L.S. Diagnosis, Rebecca Luker Is ‘Proud I Can Still Sing’
description: The Broadway soprano can no longer walk. But by propping herself up on the arms of her wheelchair, she can deliver a song. And on Wednesday night, she will.
content: It takes a lot for Rebecca Luker to sing these days.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Howard Megdal
title: W.N.B.A. and Players Agree to Plan for 22-Game Season Starting in July
description: Many details remain to be ironed out, but the plan calls for players who participate to receive 100 percent of their 2020 salaries.
content: W.N.B.A. players have ratified a plan between the league and the players’ union to play a 22-game season, beginning in late July, along with a full playoff schedule, all at IMG Academy in Bradenton, Fla., the league announced Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Calls to Abolish the Police
description: Readers react to an opinion piece that argued that reform is not enough.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ali Drucker
title: Why Weren’t We Video Calling All Along?
description: The dark, maybe selfish, truth is that we could have checked in more often long before the pandemic.
content: A couple of weeks ago, my mother and father, my sister and brother-in-law, and my fiancé and I had our first-ever group FaceTime.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stanley Reed
title: BP Prepares for a Future That Needs Less Oil
description: The energy giant said its oil and gas assets were worth less, a move reflecting broad changes in the industry.
content: BP sent a signal to investors on Monday that the economic shock of the pandemic would reverberate for years, and that less gas and oil would probably be needed in the future.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Thomas
title: F.D.A. Revokes Emergency Approval of Malaria Drugs Promoted by Trump
description: The agency said that a review of some studies showed that the drugs’ potential benefits in treating Covid-19 did not outweigh the risks.
content: The Food and Drug Administration said on Monday that it was revoking emergency authorization of two malaria drugs to treat Covid-19 in hospitalized patients, saying that they are “unlikely to be effective” and could carry potential risks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shane Goldmacher
title: Biden and D.N.C. Raised Nearly $81 Million in May, a New High
description: The former vice president had struggled with fund-raising throughout much of the primary campaign, but the pace of giving has sharply increased.
content: Joseph R. Biden Jr. and the Democratic National Committee had, by far, their biggest fund-raising month of the campaign in May, pulling in $80.8 million as large and small donors alike consolidated behind the presumptive Democratic nominee ahead of his fall contest with President Trump.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Thomas
title: F.D.A. Revokes Emergency Approval of Malaria Drugs Promoted by Trump
description: The agency said that a review of some studies showed that the drugs’ potential benefits in treating Covid-19 did not outweigh the risks.

source.name: The New York Times

title: With New Policies, Cities Seek a ‘Seismic Shift’ in Policing
description: The district attorney for Atlanta has said he will decide by midweek on whether to file criminal charges in the fatal police shooting of Rayshard Brooks.
content: This briefing has ended.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Perlroth
title: A Conspiracy Made in America May Have Been Spread by Russia
description: The Americans who pushed a conspiracy theory the night of the Iowa caucuses have migrated to coronavirus conspiracies on Twitter, with help from a very Russia-friendly account.
content: The night of the Iowa caucuses in February, Robby Mook, Hillary Clinton’s 2016 campaign manager, logged into Twitter to find the hashtag #RobbyMookCaucusApp trending across the country. Pundits on both sides of the aisle accused him of developing a mobile app to rig the Democratic primary against Senator Bernie Sanders.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Santora
title: In Europe, Travel Returns, but Not Confidence About What Comes Next
description: Borders and businesses are reopening, even as politicians and scientists warn that new waves of coronavirus infection might be on the way.
content: LONDON — Europe’s internal borders, closed three months ago in a frenzy of panicked uncertainty, are opening again. The uncertainty remains even if the sense of panic has eased.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler
title: Ireland’s 2 Main Parties to Jointly Govern for First Time
description: The deal between Fianna Fail and Fine Gael attests to the diminished stature of Ireland’s traditional parties as its political landscape fractures and as support for Sinn Fein grows.
content: LONDON — Four months after an election that brought down its government but settled little else, Ireland’s two main parties struck an agreement Monday to govern together for the first time, opening an unpredictable chapter in Irish politics as the country faces the economic fallout from the coronavirus pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Pence Tells Governors to Repeat Misleading Claim on Outbreaks
description: Cash-starved states are forced to make massive job cuts. Reopenings for some restaurants and bars are short-lived amid new infections.
content: Vice President Mike Pence encouraged governors on Monday to adopt the administration’s claim that increased testing helps account for the new coronavirus outbreak reports, even though evidence has shown that the explanation is misleading.
source.name: The New York Times
